I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The Asian Development Outlook (ADO) has been a flagship publication of the Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) since 1989. By regularly monitoring and providing comprehensive 
analysis on the evolving developments in ADB's developing member countries (DMCs), the 
publication has become one of ADB’s main vehicles for enhancing its reputation as a credible 
and authoritative source of knowledge about the region. The ADO also contributes to the 
intellectual  environment  in  which  policy  formulation  occurs.  Its  content  informs  ADB 
Management opinion and guides institutional views about prospective developments and other 
important  issues.  The  production  of  the  ADO  has  been  regularly  supported  by  technical 
assistance (TA) funding. The objectives, scope, and activities to be covered by the regional TA1 
are in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  Efforts to improve the quality of the ADO have intensified in recent years in response to 
clients’ feedback and the rapidly changing marketplace for economic information and analysis. 
These  efforts  have  focused  on  providing  stronger  analytical  content  and  ensuring  better 
cohesion and balance among its parts. If the ADO is to remain competitive and relevant as an 
independent and credible source of knowledge and information about the region, continuous 
work must be done to further improve the quality of its analysis. Activities will include the 
commissioning of relevant applied and policy research at a country and regional level, the 
development of new sources of information, and strengthened peer review. High-quality editing 
services are crucial to ensure that the ADO’s key messages are communicated clearly and 
effectively.  To  increase  the  ADO’s  regional  and  international  reach,  the  Economics  and 
Research  Department  (ERD)  will  continue  to  collaborate  with  the  Department  of  External 
Relations (DER) on further promoting the ADO. 
 
3.  The ADO is one of the most frequently downloaded publications from ADB’s website.2 It 
is directly or indirectly the source of much international and national news commentary that 
features analysis, views, and opinions from ADB. Thus, a concerted effort, not just to come up 
with a high-quality publication, but also to disseminate ADO content, is essential to elevate the 
publication’s profile.  
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
4.  The TA will support activities that will contribute to high-quality and comprehensive 
economic analysis of the region and help ensure the usefulness and relevance of the ADO to 
policy dialogue and formulation in DMCs. The improved content and structure of ADO 2010 and 
its update is expected to provide in-depth, relevant, and timely assessment of the region’s 
economy. Appendix 2 contains the draft contents pages of ADO 2010 and ADO 2010 Update. 
                                                 
1  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 26 February 2009. 
2  In the last 3 years, the ADO and its Update have consistently ranked among the top ADB downloads from the 
month of launch until the following year. For instance, ADO 2007 topped the chart at number one during its March 
2007 launch and remained in the top 5 for the remainder of the year; in 2008, it ranked between 5th and 22nd until 
that year’s ADO was launched. On average, the whole publication has been downloaded around 200,000 times per 
year in the last three years. At the time of their launches, the ADO and its update have continued to generate 
significant coverage from both global and regional top-tier media, such as the Financial Times, Asian Wall Street 
Journal, and International Herald Tribune.

2   
As in the previous issues, the publication will be presenting original work on current and relevant 
themes of interest within developing Asia and the Pacific. 
 
5.  The TA will further develop and refine analytical methods to support ADB’s short- and 
medium-term country economic monitoring and reporting. The methods will also strengthen the 
economic underpinnings of country programs and strategies for the DMCs covered. 
  
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
6.  The main outputs from the TA will be ADO 2010 and ADO 2010 Update. The TA will 
support  the  following  key  activities:  preparation  of  background  analytical  papers,  further 
development and refinement of analytical methods, drafting of ADO content, economic and copy 
editing, and preparation and layout of materials for publication. The objective of the papers will 
be to provide a solid empirical and analytical foundation for ADO content. The papers will 
supplement  the  research  work  of  ADB’s  Macroeconomics  and  Finance  Research  Division 
(ERMF) on the selected topics, and will contain analysis of issues and policy implications for the 
DMCs covered using a review of existing literature, analyses of survey and macroeconomic 
data, and modeling under different scenarios. Activities for the preparation of ADO 2011 will 
also be supported under the TA.  
  
7.  To ensure accuracy, coherence, and consistency in approach across the different parts 
of the ADO, high-quality editing services are required. Economic and copy editing activities will 
be  provided  by  international consultants  working  under  the  direction  of  the  assistant chief 
economist, ERMF.  
 
8.  Workshops and training directly relevant to the preparation and strengthening of ADO 
content will also be supported by the TA. The focus will be on macroeconomic analysis, growth 
accounting, economic projections, and effective writing skills, which will target economists in 
regional departments, national officers in resident missions, and, as appropriate, government 
officials and other client groups. The objective of the training is to equip writers with the skills 
and the tools needed to craft high-quality country chapters. The training will also impart skills 
that are of broader relevance for economic and sector work, which underpins country strategies.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
9.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $500,000 (Appendix 3). The TA will be financed 
on a grant basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF—other sources). 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
10.  ADB will be the executing agency responsible for implementing and monitoring the TA. 
In particular, ERMF will implement the TA in close coordination with regional departments and 
resident missions. The assistant chief economist of ERMF, reporting to the chief economist of 
ERD, will be responsible for implementation. Given the high institutional profile of the ADO, ERD 
will report to the vice-president for Knowledge Management and Sustainable Development, the 
managing director general, and the President at critical points in its preparation. 
 
11.  The development of analytical tools and approaches to support high-quality ADO content 
will be a joint effort of ERMF economists, country economists of the regional departments and 
resident missions, national experts, international consultants, and economics editors. The TA 
will finance the procurement of information and knowledge services as may be required to

3
 
12.  ADO  workshops  are  tentatively  scheduled  for  January–February  2011  at  ADB 
headquarters. The workshops will present and discuss issues and directions on several topics 
for consideration and inclusion in the subsequent year’s ADO. The TA will cover the travel 
expenses of selected resident mission staff who will be participating in the workshops. Contents 
of country chapters and other issues will also be discussed during the workshops. 
 
13.  An estimated 15 person-months (about six consultants) of international consultants’ time 
will be required for economic and technical editing of ADO manuscripts before final publication 
of ADO 2010 and ADO 2010 Update. ADO will also require 3 person-months (about three 
consultants) of international consultancy resources for preparing background papers. Another 5 
person-months (about two consultants) of national economic consultants’ time will be required 
to assist in preparing country chapters and data sheets. The outline terms of reference for the 
consultants  and  resource  persons  are  in  Appendix  4.  The  consultants  will  be  hired  as 
individuals.3 Resource persons will also be engaged to conduct training workshops and prepare 
background papers on economic trends and prospects of selected DMCs. Consultants and 
resource  persons  will  be  engaged  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Guidelines  on  the  Use  of 
Consultants (2007, as amended from time to time). Disbursements under the TA will be made in 
accordance with the ADB Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook.4 
 
14.  The major results of ADO 2010 and ADO 2010 Update will be disseminated to the media, 
DMC policy makers, and civil society. The media launch and subsequent roadshows will be 
undertaken by ERMF in coordination with DER, while separate launches will be undertaken by 
resident  missions  in  selected  DMCs.  Roundtable  discussions  and  workshops  in  different 
academic and economic institutions will also be conducted to reach a wider audience. Both 
ADO 2010 and ADO 2010 Update will be featured on the ADB website, and printed copies will 
be distributed worldwide. In countries where there is limited broadband access, CD-ROMs will 
be made available through the resident missions. The TA may support translation of ADO into 
other languages, as may be required, to extend its audience in selected DMCs. This will be 
arranged by regional departments in consultation with the resident missions concerned and 
DER. ERMF will work with DER to attempt to capture broad and valuable client feedback.   
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
15.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 on a grant basis for 
the Asian Development Outlook 2010, and hereby reports this action to the Board. 
 
 
 
                                                 
3 The TA will involve independent studies and require rapid mobilization of the editorial consultants to ensure that 
there  are  no  delays  in  the  tight  production  schedule  of  the  publications.  In  addition,  the  experience  and 
qualifications of the individual consultants will be a primary consideration. Thus, the consultants will be hired on an 
individual basis.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  International Economics Consultants (3 person-months, three consultants) 
1.  The consultants should have excellent working experience in general macroeconomics 
and a good knowledge of the developing member country (DMC) economies. Under the direct 
supervision of the technical assistance (TA) supervising unit officer, the consultants will 
(i)  prepare essays on current issues and country reports as may be assigned; 
(ii)  work with the economics editor to ensure consistency and coherence of the 
Asian Development Outlook (ADO); and 
(iii)  perform  all  other  functions  and  responsibilities  as  may  be  assigned  by  the 
assistant  chief  economist,  Macroeconomics  and  Finance  Research  Division 
(ERMF). 
 
B.  International Economics Editor (9.5 person-months, four consultants) 
2.  Under the direct supervision of the assistant chief economist of ERMF and in consultation 
with other Asian Development Bank (ADB) staff in the Economics and Research Department 
(ERD) involved in preparing and reviewing the country chapters for ADO 2010 and ADO 2010 
Update, the economics editor will edit the manuscripts for consistency and economic content. The 
editor will assist in preparing the highlights (English version) of the publication. The editor will also 
ensure that all the data in the publication are based on the most recent information available as of 
the specified cutoff date.  
 
3.  In particular, the economics editor will 
(i)  edit the ADO for consistency with economic theory as well as empirical evidence; 
(ii)  edit the ADO for internal consistency; 
(iii)  edit the ADO for balanced coverage and degree of detail and precision; 
(iv)  check the report for structure, content, and format to ensure that it conforms to 
the prescribed requirements for the ADO; 
(v)  review the validity and accuracy of information, tables, and charts included in the  
  write-up; 
(vi)  confer with ERMF staff regarding gaps in the write-up, important questions, and 
needed revisions; 
(vii)  assist in preparing the publication highlights; 
(viii)  help prepare the key messages and review press releases for the ADO; and 
(ix)  perform  all  other  functions  and  responsibilities  as  may  be  assigned  by  the 
assistant chief economist, ERMF. 
 
C.  International  Copy  Editor-cum-Desktop  Publishing  Specialist  (5.5 person-months, 
two consultants) 
 
4.  Under the direct supervision of the assistant chief economist of ERMF, and in consultation 
with the ADO production coordinator, the copy editor will (i) edit ADO 2010 and ADO 2010 Update 
in accordance with ADB’s editorial style; (ii) be responsible for typesetting and proofreading the 
text, tables, and charts from the preliminary draft to the final copy and filming the output before 
forwarding to the external printer; (iii) be responsible for data linking to ensure data integrity and 
consistency in the final manuscript; and (iv) be responsible for converting the desktop file into pdf 
and  html  files  for  uploading  on  the  ADB  website.  The  copy  editor  must  have  full  working

knowledge of MS Office (MS Word and MS Excel), Adobe Pagemaker and InDesign, and Corel

5.  In particular, the copy editor-cum-desktop publishing specialist will  
(i)  edit the ADO in conformity with ADB’s editorial style and usage; 
(ii)  edit the ADO for consistency and accuracy; 
(iii)  edit the publication summary of the ADO; 
(iv)  supervise the encoding of corrections as well as incorporation of tables, charts, 
and boxes; 
(v)  edit the ADO for balance (in terms of layout); 
(vi)  review the final manuscript for digital printing (via pdf); 
(vii)  prepare the definition, glossary of terms, and list of references; 
(viii)  edit all dissemination materials, including press releases, speeches, questions, 
and answers, key messages, and presentation slides;  
(ix)  convert desktop files to PDF and HTML formats consistent with ADB website 
guidelines; and 
(x)  perform  all  other  functions  and  responsibilities  as  may  be  assigned  by  the 
assistant chief economist, ERMF. 
 
D.  Resource Persons 
6.  The resource persons should have excellent working experience in macro-econometric 
modeling and economic projections. In particular, they will 
(i)  provide materials for the training, and 
(ii)  conduct  training  on  macroeconomics  and  economic  projections  at  ADB 
headquarters. 
 
7.  Resource persons from selected DMCs will also be engaged to act as discussants to the 
ADO background papers which will be presented during the workshops. 
 
E.  National Economics Consultants (5 person-months, two consultants) 
8.  The consultants should have excellent working experience in general economics. Under 
the  direct  supervision  of  the  TA  supervising  unit  officer,  the  consultants  will  assist  in  the 
economic research work of ERD and undertake general economic research. In particular, they 
will 
(i)  conduct  research  on  issues  related  to  macroeconomic  development,  growth, 
trade and investment, human capital development, and long-term employment 
generation in the Asia and Pacific region; 
(ii)  support country economic analyses; 
(iii)  contribute to the preparation of ADO and its update; 
(iv)  update the ADO data sheet; and 
(v)  undertake ad hoc research and other assignments as may be assigned by the 
assistant chief economist, ERMF.
